title: 113_hr5093
content: The Act titled "Children's Firearm Marketing Safety Act" prohibits the marketing of firearms to children. The Federal Trade Commission will prohibit marketing firearms to children by implementing rules such as banning the use of cartoon characters, firearm brand merchandise for children, marketing campaigns targeting children, and manufacturing guns with child-appealing colors or designs. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce rules prohibiting the manufacturing of guns for children without clear labeling of the firearm's risks. Violations will be treated as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Violations will be treated as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act, with penalties and privileges outlined. States can also take action if their residents are affected by violations. The State, acting as parens patriae, can bring a civil action in State court to enjoin, enforce compliance, obtain damages, or seek other legal relief for residents. Before filing, the State must notify the Federal Trade Commission. The State can bring a civil action in State court as parens patriae to seek legal relief for residents. If notice before filing is not feasible, the attorney general must notify the Federal Trade Commission immediately upon filing. The Federal Trade Commission has the authority to intervene, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal in the action. The State attorney general can bring a civil action in State court as parens patriae to seek legal relief for residents. If the Federal Trade Commission or the Attorney General of the United States has initiated a civil action for a rule violation, no State entity can bring a similar action during the Federal action. Nothing in this Act prevents a State attorney general from exercising their powers to bring a civil action. The section prohibits a State from interfering with the powers of the attorney general to conduct investigations, administer oaths, compel witnesses, and produce evidence. Definitions include "child" as under 18 years old and "firearm" as defined in federal law.
